name: Myocardial Infarction - Universal Definition and Classification
content:
MYOCARDIAL INFARCTION (MI) - FOURTH UNIVERSAL DEFINITION:

DIAGNOSTIC CRITERIA (Requires ≥1):
1. Detection of rise/fall of cardiac troponin with ≥1 value >99th percentile AND ≥1 of:
   - Symptoms of myocardial ischemia
   - New ischemic ECG changes (ST-T changes, LBBB)
   - Development of pathological Q waves
   - New loss of viable myocardium or wall motion abnormality (imaging)
   - Intracoronary thrombus on angiography

CLASSIFICATION:
- Type 1: Spontaneous MI (plaque rupture, erosion, dissection)
- Type 2: MI secondary to ischemic imbalance (supply-demand mismatch)
- Type 3: Cardiac death with suspected MI (sudden death before biomarkers obtained)
- Type 4a: MI related to PCI
- Type 4b: MI related to stent thrombosis
- Type 5: MI related to CABG

STEMI vs NSTEMI:
- STEMI: ST elevation ≥1mm in ≥2 contiguous leads OR new LBBB
- NSTEMI: Troponin elevation WITHOUT ST elevation

BIOMARKERS:
- Troponin I/T: Rise detectable 2-4h, peak 12-48h, elevated 4-14 days
- High-sensitivity troponin: Earlier detection (0h, 1h, 3h protocols)

TREATMENT:
- STEMI: Immediate reperfusion (PCI <90min or thrombolysis <30min)
- NSTEMI: Risk stratification (TIMI/GRACE score), early invasive vs conservative
- Antiplatelet: Dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin + P2Y12 inhibitor)
- Anticoagulation: Heparin/enoxaparin
- Adjuncts: Beta-blocker, ACE-I, statin
